channel.title: Science 10 Chemistry - Balancing Equation
channel.description:
"Balance the following equation. If not coefficient is required in the equation, write "1" in the blank space.
___MgN2(s) + ___H20(l) --> ___Mg(OH)2(aq) + ___NH3(g)
Could some try their best to explain it to me =/

item.title: Science 10 Chemistry - Balancing Equation
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:10, topic:398355”]http://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=Mg3N2+%2B+H2O+->+Mg(OH)2+%2B+NH3
it tells you the names as well[/quote]
Wolframalpha is godlike.

Read full topic

item.title: Science 10 Chemistry - Balancing Equation
item.dc:creator: @Rixxx Rix_
item.description:
@Rixxx wrote:

You’re being careless. It’s Mg[size=6pt]3[/size]N[size=6pt]2[/size] (magnesium nitride) and it reacts with water to produce magnesium hydroxide and ammonia gas.

The left-hand side of the equation must equal the right-hand side of the equation.
Mg[size=6pt]3[/size]N[size=6pt]2[/size] + H[size=6pt]2[/size]O -> Mg(OH)[size=6pt]2[/size] + NH[size=6pt]3[/size]

Since the LHS has 3 Mg but the RHS has 1 Mg, we need to make sure the RHS has 3 Mg as well.
Mg[size=6pt]3[/size]N[size=6pt]2[/size] + H[size=6pt]2[/size]O -> 3Mg(OH)[size=6pt]2[/size] + NH[size=6pt]3[/size]

Now that the Mg count in both sides are the same, we notice that RHS has 6 O but LHS only has 1. Balance it.
Mg[size=6pt]3[/size]N[size=6pt]2[/size] + 6H[size=6pt]2[/size]O -> 3Mg(OH)[size=6pt]2[/size] + NH[size=6pt]3[/size]

Now everything is balanced except N and H, you’ll end up with this:
Mg[size=6pt]3[/size]N[size=6pt]2[/size] + 6H[size=6pt]2[/size]O -> 3Mg(OH)[size=6pt]2[/size] + 2NH[size=6pt]3[/size]

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @chrisn2323 chrisn2323
item.description:

I’ll give you a hint: MgN2(s) does not exist.

Count the electrons and make sure they’re equal on both sides. Basically a puzzle.
[/quote]
not electrons[/quote]
It’s been awhile, what is it then?

Nevermind.

item.title: Science 10 Chemistry - Balancing Equation
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

lawl_temp:

btw wolframalpha can balance chemical equations

That does not help you on tests. (At least not in this country). The best way is to just do it sometimes and learn it.
OP: Just try sometimes and find the way that fit you best. Like start with the simples part…

Read full topic

item.title: Science 10 Chemistry - Balancing Equation
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

[quote=“lawl_temp, post:3, topic:398355”][quote author=T4_ link=topic=495489.msg3622626#msg3622626 date=1307565564]
Count the electrons and make sure they’re equal on both sides. Basically a puzzle.
[/quote]
not electrons[/quote]
Chemical elements.
Check that both sides are equal.

OP: Your equation won’t go up, fix your error and find the answer yourself. If you don’t even manage this, you will get huge problems later. (And chemistry isn’t hard the first year)

Read full topic
